title: Can a collection agency buy a debt that has been discharged in BK and get payments?
question: I filed BK in 2010 and got all debts dischared including the debt from hsbc, this collection agency called second time around LP purchased the debt and want me to pay them is this legal?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Credit,Debt,Debt relief,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,Employment,Fees,Court orders
answers: When you receive a discharge the legal obligation to pay the discharge debt is eliminated. Even if the debt is later sold to a collection agency, the agency only has the same rights that the original creditor had. So, if you have a defense against the debt by claiming that the debt was discharged against the original creditor, the same defense will apply against the collection agency that purchased the debt. In short, the collection company will stand in the shoes of the original creditor, and is subject to the same defenses as well.

No, furthermore it is a violation of the discharge injunction. Send them a certified letter return receipt informing them that the debt was discharged in bankruptcy. Give your bankruptcy case number. If they attempt to collect after that you can sue them.

No. This is a violation of something called the "discharged injunction." (Section 524 of the Code). I encourage you to keep good notes of every telephone call (name of caller, name of debt collector, time of call, duration of call, telephone number on caller id etc etc.) I would also encourage you to contact your attorney about this matter immediately. A violation of the discharge injunction is considered a violation of a court order that could result in a finding of contempt. In addition, the creditor may be ordered to compensate you for the nuisance and any economic damages along with attorney's fees.

In some jurisdictions, the violation of the discharge injunction may be considered a violation of other statutes such as the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA), Rosenthal Act, the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) if the creditor provides false information to credit reporting agencies, and the version of the consumer fraud statute for your State.

The debt collection effort is probably a technical violation of the discharge injunction of your bankruptcy. At this point, I would give the new collection agency the benefit of the doubt, send them a copy of the bankruptcy discharge and tell them not to bother you anymore. Save copies of all the back and forth correspondence, keep notes of any phone calls and write down all the details. If the agency continues to attempt to collect, get a consultation with a lawyer.

Just like all of the other attorneys have stated, they cannot collect on discharged debt and are actually violating the bankruptcy court's discharge order. Get an attorney to fight them if they continue contacting you and you may be entitled to a pretty good amount of money plus attorney fees.

Well, sure a debt buyer can buy the debt, but they cannot collect on it as it was discharged. If you were my bankruptcy client I would want you to call and tell me about this. I would ask for a copy of the letter (with the envelope). I would likely send a strongly worded letter about your case and their bankruptcy and collection law violations. If they did it again I would sue them.

Good luck,


Robert Kovacs

If the debt was included in your bankruptcy case (post-petition debt?), unsecured and not reaffirmed, then the answer is "NO".

In fact, if the above is true, then the creditor/collector may be in violation of your discharge injunction and damages, including attorney fees and costs may be awarded to you for your efforts to enforce your Bankruptcy Discharge Order.

Seek the counsel of a bankruptcy attorney to learn more about this and what next steps to take. For more information you may wish to visit: www.salanicklaw.com

Best of luck!
No, you have been discharged of the debt. This is a violation of the FDCPA and the Injunctive nature of a bankruptcy discharge.

The debt is discharged, they cannot collect, and their efforts to collect violate the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act and the Rosenthal Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. If they call again, tell them that, get their name and number and say you will sue them if they call again.
